name: Mukden Incident / Manchuria seizure
short_desc: Japanese Kwantung Army stages the Mukden Incident and uses it to seize Manchuria.
label: 01. Mukden Incident (1931)

name: Marco Polo Bridge Incident / Full-scale war in China
short_desc: Skirmish at the Marco Polo Bridge sparks full-scale Sino-Japanese war.
label: 02. Marco Polo Bridge (1937)

name: France surrenders; Japan expands into French Indochina
short_desc: Japan pressures French authorities and occupies parts of Indochina; US tightens embargoes.
label: 03. French Indochina (1940–41)

name: Pearl Harbor (attack)
short_desc: Japanese carrier-based aircraft attack U.S. Pacific Fleet at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
label: 04. Pearl Harbor (Dec 7

name: Philippines attacks (initial landings)
short_desc: Japanese forces initiate attacks and landings across the Philippines.
label: 05. Philippines (Dec 8–10

name: Malaya attacks (initial)
short_desc: Japanese invasion of Malaya begins, leading to rapid conquest of peninsula.
label: 06. Malaya (Dec 7–10

name: Hong Kong falls
short_desc: British colony of Hong Kong surrenders after sustained Japanese assault.
label: 07. Hong Kong (Dec 8–25

name: Guam captured
short_desc: Japanese forces capture U.S. possession of Guam early in the war.
label: 08. Guam (Dec 7–10

name: Thailand attacked/entry
short_desc: Japanese invasion moves through Thailand as part of the initial offensive.
label: 09. Thailand (Dec 8

name: Wake Island siege
short_desc: Japanese forces besiege and capture Wake Island after initial resistance.
label: 10. Wake Island (Dec 8–23

name: Solomon Islands campaign (key sites: Rabaul)
short_desc: Japanese garrison at Rabaul becomes major Allied target in the Solomons-New Guinea theater.
label: 11. Rabaul (1942–45)

name: Singapore surrenders
short_desc: British forces in Singapore surrender to advancing Japanese troops.
label: 12. Singapore (Feb 15

name: Bombing of Darwin
short_desc: Japanese carrier-based aircraft bomb the Australian port of Darwin.
label: 13. Darwin (Feb 19

name: Bataan Death March begins
short_desc: Following surrender at Bataan, Allied POWs begin forced march under Japanese control.
label: 14. Bataan Death March (Apr 1942)

name: Doolittle Raid (Tokyo strike)
short_desc: USAAF carriers launch a raid on Tokyo and other Japanese cities; limited damage but major morale effect.
label: 15. Doolittle Raid (Apr 18

name: Coral Sea
short_desc: Carrier battle that stops Japanese seaborne advance toward Port Moresby.
label: 16. Coral Sea (May 4–8

name: Aleutian Islands seized (Attu/Kiska)
short_desc: Japanese occupy parts of the Aleutian chain as diversion and northern front.
label: 17. Aleutians (June 1942)

name: Midway
short_desc: Decisive carrier battle at Midway halts Japanese offensive and shifts balance.
label: 18. Midway (June 4–7

name: Guadalcanal (landings)
short_desc: U.S. amphibious landings begin the long campaign to seize Guadalcanal and its airfield.
label: 19. Guadalcanal (Aug 7

name: Gilbert & Marshall Islands campaign begins
short_desc: Allied island-hopping campaign targets Gilberts and Marshalls to move toward Japan.
label: 20. Gilbert & Marshall (1942–44)

name: Aleutians retaken (Attu)
short_desc: US forces retake Attu (and later Kiska), removing Japanese presence in Aleutians.
label: 21. Aleutians retaken (1943)

name: Tarawa
short_desc: One of the first major U.S. amphibious assaults on a heavily defended atoll.
label: 22. Tarawa (Nov 20–23

name: Saipan
short_desc: Capture of Saipan brings B-29 bases within range of Japan.
label: 23. Saipan (Jun 15–Jul 9

name: Great Marianas Turkey Shoot / Philippine Sea
short_desc: Massive carrier-air engagement inflicting heavy Japanese losses in aircraft.
label: 24. Philippine Sea (Jun 19–20

name: MacArthur returns to Philippines (Leyte landings)
short_desc: General MacArthur's forces land on Leyte, beginning liberation of the Philippines.
label: 25. Leyte (Oct 20

name: Leyte Gulf
short_desc: Largest naval battle in modern history disrupts Japanese fleet and supply lines.
label: 26. Leyte Gulf (Oct 23–26

name: Iwo Jima
short_desc: U.S. Marines capture strategically placed island and its airfields; famous Mt. Suribachi flag raising.
label: 27. Iwo Jima (Feb 19–Mar 26

name: Flag raising
short_desc: flag-raising
source_url: Iconic U.S. flag-raising on Mt. Suribachi during the Iwo Jima campaign.
label: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg

name: Tokyo firebombing
short_desc: Massive U.S. incendiary raids cause widespread destruction in Tokyo.
label: 29. Tokyo firebombing (Mar 9–10

name: Okinawa
short_desc: Largest amphibious assault in the Pacific, with heavy casualties on both sides.
label: 30. Okinawa (Apr 1–Jun 22

name: Battleship Yamato sunk
short_desc: U.S. carrier aircraft sink the Japanese battleship Yamato during Operation Ten-Go.
label: 31. Yamato sunk (Apr 7

name: USS Indianapolis sunk
short_desc: Heavy cruiser USS Indianapolis is torpedoed and sunk, with great loss of life at sea.
label: 32. USS Indianapolis (Jul 30

name: Hiroshima (atomic)
short_desc: U.S. atomic bomb detonates over Hiroshima; devastating immediate and long-term effects.
label: 33. Hiroshima (Aug 6

name: Nagasaki (atomic)
short_desc: U.S. atomic bomb detonates over Nagasaki; Japan moves toward surrender.
label: 34. Nagasaki (Aug 9

name: Emperor announces defeat / V-J Day
short_desc: Emperor Hirohito announces Japan's acceptance of Allied terms leading to end of hostilities.
label: 35. Emperor's announcement (Aug 15

name: Surrender signing
short_desc: surrender
source_url: Formal Japanese surrender signing aboard USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay.
label: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg
